subject: OS-7260 SmartOS should support booting with loader OS-7309 build tools should support loader-based boot images HEAD-2249 boot menu should show PI version TRITON-855 Triton headnode tools need to handle new boot architecture TRITON-933 Put mount-usb.sh out
commitMessage:
OS-7260 SmartOS should support booting with loader
OS-7309 build tools should support loader-based boot images
HEAD-2249 boot menu should show PI version
TRITON-855 Triton headnode tools need to handle new boot architecture
TRITON-933 Put mount-usb.sh out to pasture
TRITON-1016 Need to build and deliver the ipxe EFI binary
Reviewed by: Josh Wilsdon <josh@wilsdon.ca>
Approved by: Josh Wilsdon <josh@wilsdon.ca>

Patch Set 11: Patch Set 10 was rebased

Patch Set 11: Integration-Approval+1

While I'm not a fan of the images I've seen of the new boot screen, it doesn't seem like style (or lack thereof) should block this feature. I assume we can make improvements to that later. And having read through the test notes, I can't think of anything further that needs to be tested before this is integrated so +1 from me for IA.
Uploaded patch set 12: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by John Levon
I'm not clear on what COAL booting looks like after this. Is there still a menu with an option to boot as a CN, for example?
The ipxe option is still there, it's just not the default.

This possibly adds a dependency on the headnode that we are reflashing being in a slightly more reasonable state than just having /usbkey/... copied from the USB key.

Practically I'm not sure if that's a legitimate issues, however, so I'm fine using this.

As part of new CN setup (https://github.com/joyent/sdc-cnapi/blob/master/lib/workflows/server-setup.js#L106) the joysetup.sh script is downloaded on the CN and run there. Won't this new include file break on older platforms?

So as of yesterday, I now have a CN to test on (and figure out how updates work). You are probably right, and we'll have to keep around the old code for a newly minted CN that's brought up into an older PI (right?)

Some more investigation: we need to do this for update-usbkey script, so I'll just duplicate usb-key.sh there.

For this script, the only way we can not have this include file is if we update gz tools, do a factory reset and end up here again, but with an old PI. In such a case, I think we should/can assert that the key is grub.
nit: whitespace mixed tabs and spaces
We're going to remove this file altogether.
I'm not sure what happens if `sdc-usbkey unmount` exits non-zero here: (a) `set -o errexit` would initiate an exit, but (b) we are already in a trap for EXIT.
I should probably fix this to just complain.
Nit: tabs when the file otherwise uses 4-space indentation.

Having names for all functions can help when digging through node.js cores.

However, currently sdc-usbkey isn't being run with `node --abort-on-uncaught-exception` which would be required to get cores.

Your call. Our best practice has become to definitely do that for the node.js *services*. I don't know if an established rule/suggestion/best-practice for CLIs.  There isn't a strong reason to *not* do it, and that core might be quite nice the first time you get a support ticket on sdc-usbkey failure.
At the least, dhcpd does do it, so I will too.
Was there intent to have these in lexographical order? I.e. script '0' before script '5' in the /opt/smartdc/usbkey/share dir? Does glob.sync doc that it guarantees lexo order of results?

Or require the files to have 2 digits (by using "foo.??.*" for the glob pattern)?

The node-glob docs say "The matches are sorted, unless the nosort flag is set." so that's fine then.
I'm going to leave this. If we ever reach 10 scripts, we can just name them slightly more awkwardly.
looks like a tab snuck in here where it doesn't belong.
Why do we include all the tty devices that the user *didn't* specify? This seems like it's worth a comment.
This is what grub did but I'll explain this a little more.
Is this a typo of DISKPATH?
Why not use DISK_PATTERN then? It doesn't look like we're space-constrained here.
How so? Perhaps point this at a ticket instead?
This needs SUCMD because $IMG_TMP_DIR/${OUTPUT_IMG} might be owned by root?
